001package imagingbook.common.util;
002
003import java.util.stream.IntStream;
004
005/**
006 * Determines the 'permutation' of a sequence of numbers and
007 * keeps it as an array ({@link #perm}) of position indexes.
008 * These indexes indicate how the original input array
009 * may be re-ordered to become sorted
010 * (see {@link #getPermutation()}).
011 * 
012 * @author WB
013 *
014 */
015public class SortMap {
016        
017        private final int[] perm;
018        
019        /**
020         * Constructor for {@code double[]}. The input array is not modified.
021         * @param numbers the input array
022         */
023        public SortMap(double[] numbers) {
024                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
025                        .sorted((i, j) -> Double.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
026                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
027        }
028        
029        /**
030         * Constructor for {@code float[]}. The input array is not modified.
031         * @param numbers the input array
032         */
033        public SortMap(float[] numbers) {
034                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
035                        .sorted((i, j) -> Float.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
036                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
037        }
038        
039        /**
040         * Constructor for {@code int[]}. The input array is not modified.
041         * @param numbers the input array
042         */
043        public SortMap(int[] numbers) {
044                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
045                        .sorted((i, j) -> Integer.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
046                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
047        }
048        
049        // --------------------------------------------------
050        
051        /**
052         * Returns the permutation (sorted position indexes) for the underlying
053         * number sequence ({@code numbers}) as a {@code int} array.
054         * That is, the first value in the returned array is the index
055         * of the smallest element in {@code numbers}, the second element
056         * points to the second-smallest element, etc.
057         * For example, if the original number sequence (passed to the constructor) is
058         * <pre>numbers = (50.0, 20.0, 100.0, 120.0, 40.0, -10.0)</pre>
059         * then the permutation array returned by {@link #getPermutation()} is
060         * <pre>perm = (5, 1, 4, 0, 2, 3)</pre>
061         * This means that 
062         * <pre>numbers[perm[i]] &le; numbers[perm[i+1]]</pre>
063         * and thus the sequence
064         * <pre>(numbers[perm[0]], numbers[perm[1]],..., numbers[perm[N-1]])</pre>
065         * is sorted.
066         * 
067         * @return the sorting map (permutation)
068         */
069        public int[] getPermutation() {
070                return this.perm;
071        }
072        
073        /**
074         * Returns the index of the n-th smallest element of the original number sequence
075         * (passed to the constructor),
076         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the index of the smallest element.
077         * 
078         * @param n the index
079         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element in the original number sequence
080         */
081        public int getIndex(int n) {
082                if (n < 0 || n >= perm.length) {
083                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("position index n out of range: " + n);
084                }
085                return perm[n];
086        }
087        
088        // --------------------------------------------------
089        
090        /**
091         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified  {@code double[]},
092         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element.
093         * 
094         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
095         * @param n the index
096         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
097         */
098        public static double getNthSmallest(double[] numbers, int n) {
099                int idx = new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
100                return numbers[idx];
101        }
102        
103        /**
104         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified {@code float[]},
105         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element.
106         * 
107         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
108         * @param n the index
109         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
110         */
111        public static float getNthSmallest(float[] numbers, int n) {
112                int idx = new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
113                return numbers[idx];
114        }
115        
116        /**
117         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified {@code int[]},
118         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element.
119         * 
120         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
121         * @param n the index
122         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
123         */
124        public static int getNthSmallest(int[] numbers, int n) {
125                int idx = new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
126                return numbers[idx];
127        }
128        
129
130}
